instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
Hey Everyone!

Got a 2010 MBP, no sign of liquid damage found.
No green light.
PP3V42 is present.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> rail is not present.

Checked resistance around each component with the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all seem to show 0.24 Ohms (in 20K setting).
Not sure what to check next or where to go from here.

Thanks,
Sam

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 voltages.
Check contimuity between <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and pin central of magsafe connector.
Also check resistance to ground at L6995 on 200K scale.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is OK?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6900</CHIP> - 0V all round
<CHIP>U6901</CHIP> - pin 1 (<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>) shows 0.01V, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> shows 3.40V and all other pins show 0V.

Not sure how to check continuity, SORRY!

Resistance to ground on both ends for L6995 shows around 51.0 (on 200K scale).

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> seems good (all components showing 3.4V)

Thank you!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message: ACOK is missing so that is a problem. Check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and voltage there, also check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22/51/52. If any of those are dead then also replace the ISL.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>: Pin 1 shows 16.45V (81 Ohms in 200K setting) and pin 2 fluctuates between 1.45V and 2.1V and inbetween them (84.3Ohms in 200K setting).

<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22: The resistance seems to keep going up or keep going down at differing times when i take measurements. (around 2M setting and just gradually goes bigger or smaller) and both shows 0.93V all round.

<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52: Both shows 0V all round. 
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>: Pin 1 shows 0.004 (2K setting) and Pin 2 shows 0.23 (20K setting)
<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>: Pin 1 shows 0.23 (20K setting) and Pin 2 shows 0.23 (20K setting)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message: Replace ISL, <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 from ISL.... Post measurements results.....

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
Okay so ISL replaced, green light shows but fan doesn't spin and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 0.46V. <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> shows 16.75V on both ends now.

Pins 17/18 flactuating alot not able to get a stabilised measurement.
Pin 27/28 also flactuating.

Should I still also replace <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> should be 20 Ohm. Need to know resistance between pins 17/18 27/28.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
Pin 17/18 shows around 104 Ohms and 27/28 shows 10 Ohms

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> shows 1.46 kOhms

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message: Replace <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 and see if that fixes your issue

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
Replaced <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> and its giving the same issues.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still giving different value of 0.53V.

Forgot to mention but getting 3.24V on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and 3.4V on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL>.

Anymore suggestions or would you like any more readings.
Thank you.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message: Replaced yes, have you then checked them? Resistance between pins 17/18 27/28 and voltage on DCIN pin?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
To be sure, are you measuring these resistance values with power applied or not?

Also see dukes response above

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>: The voltage is 16.75V

27/28: gives 20Ohms
17/18: gives 0 Ohms ---- i'm gonna check my <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> again, its giving 0 Ohms and not giving 2.2 Ohms and the <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> is giving 0 Ohms aswell.

I am measuring resistance without power applied.

Thanks, Sam

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="SamMac, post: 29567"]<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>: The voltage is 16.75V


17/18: gives 0 Ohms ---- i'm gonna check my <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> again, its giving 0 Ohms and not giving 2.2 Ohms and the <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> is giving 0 Ohms aswell.

Thanks, Sam[/QUOTE]

Seems like corroded/broken traces to me. Inspect circuit coming out of pins 17/18

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No power // no green light
threads.message:
How can corroded tracks cause a lower resistance?
<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> is supposed to be 0 Ohm. <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> is the one that causes the 2.2 Ohm reading.
